history.content: I don't quite see the difference? Seeing as all the design courses are cs/ee/eecs

children.subject: You also need to take 7 units of technical electives, so you are implying that you also don’t want to use any CS courses to fulfill that requirement?

First and foremost, I would like to thank the EECS department for creating extremely lenient degree requirements for LSCS. It has given me great freedom to pursue a variety of interests within my education.

I just think this would give a little more flexibility when selecting courses. This is just a suggestion that I thought would be nice. 

For example with the suggested change, the following course schedule could be possible: 3 EE/EECS courses, 1 CS(design), 1 CS(non-Design) course.  

At the end of the day, there would still be two cs courses and a design course within the five courses or 20+ units.

You need a minimum of 8 units of CS for your CS major. As the student above inferred, the remaining 19 units of upper-division could be in EE/EECS, with 7 of those units coming from this list, if interested. Eight units of CS is two classes and you get to pick which two. You then have a lot of freedom to choose which five remaining classes will fulfill the rest of the requirements. Feel free to contact cs-advising with more requirement questions if you're still unclear.

history.content:
As of so far, the current upper-division requirements for cs major include 2 upper-division cs courses, 1 design course, and 2 cs/ee/eecs courses.

Would it be possible to change these requirements to 3 cs/ee/eecs courses and 2 cs courses with one of these five courses being a design course?
history.subject: CS Upper Division Requirements
